prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Reglefurn Encounter  

Across the reglet-lumbered lane,  
Where ink-cots creak and benches brood,  
The chair-clad shadows softly wane,  
In finch-fumed folds of varnish wood.  

“Beware the Reglefurn!” they cried,  
“With dovelip jaws it snarls the beam;  
It lurks where polish pools to hide,  
Then seeps between the grainy seam.”  

I gripped my knurl-ed winder-stick,  
A splinterbright, quick-silver blade;  
I donned a brace of mortise brick,  
And bound my courage, walnut-made.  

Through dovetail woods I stalked at dusk;  
The peg-wind sang a tenon tune;  
Each hinge-leaf whispered resin musk,  
Beneath a crescent copper moon.  

SKRRR-crack-a-CLANG! it burst from gloom,  
The Reglefurn with dowel roar;  
I whirled my blade—CLACK-WHISH-ka-BOOM!  
It clove the beast from peg to floor.  

Back benchward home I strode, oak-spry;  
The shavings cheered in spiral swarms;  
“Rejoice!” the trestle tongues did cry,  
“Our joiner’s heart has stilled the storms.”  

Still, ’cross that reglet-lumbered lane,  
The varnish keeps its whisper low;  
Yet benches know, in walnut grain,  
How steel once hushed the hinge-wind’s woe.
label: high
judge_raw:

<C1_think>Title line "The Reglefurn Encounter" present before first stanza, non-empty, separate from stanza text.</C1_think>

<C4_think>Rhyme scheme favors (2,4) rhyming lines in majority of stanzas, with varied rhymes and no AABB dominance; slant rhyme accepted (e.g. "beam/seam", "gloom/room" equivalents), so ≥60% stanzas show (2,4) rhyme.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes opening stanza in theme and some words (e.g., "reglet-lumbered lane", "bench", "varnish"), but not exact repeated content words or clear refrain of ≥2 distinct content words; echo is thematic but not a direct ring phrase or repeated content words.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early stanza 2 contains explicit admonition: “Beware the Reglefurn!”— clear early warning to protagonist.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Stanza 3 shows clear preparation and armament: "I gripped my knurl-ed winder-stick", "a splinterbright, quick-silver blade", "donned a brace", and "bound my courage" indicate preparation and resolve.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Stanza 5 shows a clear encounter and confrontation with the Reglefurn; vivid action of attack and beast bursting “from gloom.”</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive slaying action in stanza 5: protagonist “clove the beast from peg to floor,” resolving central tension.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration in stanza 6 with cheering “shavings” and “trestle tongues” rejoicing protagonist’s success; jubilant acknowledgement present.</C10_think>

<C14_think>Onomatopoeia bursts present notably in stanza 5: “SKRRR-crack-a-CLANG!”, “CLACK-WHISH-ka-BOOM!” — at least two distinct onomatopoeic bursts.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Clear alliteration and consonance present in at least two stanzas, e.g., “knurl-ed winder-stick,” “splinterbright, quick-silver blade,” “peg-wind sang a tenon tune,” “bench-clad shadows softly wane,” “spiral swarms,” “trestle tongues.”</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order is canonical: warning (stanza 2) → preparation (3) → encounter (5) → decisive action (5) → return/celebration (6) in correct order.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines exactly match any from the canonical poem; all original wording.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical words are absent or minimal; no canonical lexicon from Carroll’s poem present, so distinct canonical tokens = 0 ≤ 8.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Line syllable counts per stanza align reasonably with Jabberwocky’s meter: longer lines mostly ~8–9 syllables, shorter lines ~5–7 syllables consistently in all quatrains.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme (2,4) endings are varied across stanzas with no overuse of exact end words (>2 times); rhyme words distinct and avoid repetition.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No lexical overuse detected; no content word repeated > 5 times overall or > 8% of total content words, outside metaphorical echoes.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages display a broad variety of distinct roots: multiple different compound bases and invented forms; no single suffix or root accounts for >50% coinages.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic adherence is clear: poem addresses a Lewis Carroll style nonsense poem with similar structure and motifs, central confrontation with a nonsensical creature, fitting original topic.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext present: metaphor of woodworking/joinery imagery aligned with conflict and resolution, with undertones of craftsmanship, courage, and taming a wild force, adding coherent implied layers beyond surface action.</C24_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Twiltscrew and the Screwdrake

’Twas twiltscrew, and the clockish gears,  
They drummed round and roundly;  
A blued screw in its movement veers,  
Through twankling tick-tock ground.  

“Beware the Screwdrake, child,” she said,  
“That clink-clawed coilish fiend!  
Its rivet fangs will gnash you dead,  
Its whirlwinds grind unseen.”  

He gripped his spanner-saber bright,  
The sprocketshield in tow;  
He practiced thrusts through gearing night,  
In silent lantern-glow.  

Ka-CLANG! the Screwdrake burst the cogs,  
Steamspittle filled the air;  
It skirled among the oiled-up sprogs,  
With riv’nous ratchet glare.  

Whizz-whirr the steely sabre swung,  
Klink-klank the tempered bite;  
The Screwdrake screeched with sprocket-tongue,  
Then fell from gearful height.  

He hoisted home the blued-paced head,  
Through corridors of chime;  
His mother oiled the wounds he bled,  
And wound the watch of time.  

’Twas twiltscrew, and the clockish gears,  
They drummed round and roundly;  
The blued screw in its movement steers,  
Mid soft tick-tock soundly.
label: high

The meter is uneven; some alternating lines have clear longer/shorter rhythm (e.g., first stanza roughly 8 and 6 syllables), but not consistently across 5+ stanzas. Only 3 stanzas with clear rhyme (4,5,6,7), about 57% or so. Borderline, but since we require ≥60% clearly, no.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes opening stanza with repeated words/phrases: "’Twas twiltscrew," "clockish gears," "drummed round," "roundly," "blued screw," and "tick-tock"—at least two content words repeated clearly—yes ring composition.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present: stanza 2 says "Beware the Screwdrake, child," a direct caution to protagonist - yes.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation/armament before encounter: stanza 3, protagonist "gripped his spanner-saber," "practiced thrusts," and "silent lantern-glow" suggests readiness and training before confrontation - yes.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear encounter/confrontation in stanza 4: "Ka-CLANG! the Screwdrake burst the cogs," described attack by adversary - yes.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive act resolving tension: stanza 5, "Whizz-whirr the steely sabre swung," "The Screwdrake screeched... then fell" shows decisive slaying action - yes.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return/celebration: stanza 6 depicts return home "He hoisted home... His mother oiled the wounds... wound the watch of time," a calm acknowledgment, less jubilant than canonical but clear return and care - yes.</C10_think>

<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coinage: e.g., twiltscrew, clockish, twankling, spanner-saber, steamspittle, whizz-whirr, klink-klank, blued-paced - yes.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Non-canonical creature named and central: "Screwdrake" named and main adversary - yes.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia bursts: "Ka-CLANG!" (stanza 4), "Whizz-whirr," "Klink-klank" (stanza 5) clearly onomatopoeic bursts, ≥2 present - yes.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance in multiple stanzas: e.g., stanza 1 "clockish gears," stanza 2 "clink-clawed coilish," stanza 4 "steamspittle," "sprogs," stanza 5 "steely sabre swung," "screeched," stanza 6 "hoisted home" - at least 2 stanzas with clear alliteration - yes.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order canonical: admonition (stanza 2), preparation (3), encounter (4), decisive action (5), return/celebration (6), final ring echo (7) - order preserved - yes.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No verbatim canonical lines: all lines rewritten with new words, no direct repeats - yes.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical word usage: very limited to none of the classic canonical list; most words are new coinages or standard English, well below 8 canonical tokens - yes.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable counts and meter: longer lines generally near 8-9 syllables, shorter lines near 5-7 syllables, e.g. stanza 1 line 1 (8 syll), line 2 (6 syll); stanza 4 lines mostly variable but close to pattern. Around all stanzas meet this pattern - yes.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety: the rhymes that exist vary, no repeated exact rhyme words more than twice (excluding ring echo) - yes.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No lexical repetition overused: no single content word appears >5 times or excessive percentage; many coinages reduce repetition - yes.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinage variety: coinages show diverse roots (twiltscrew, spanner, sprocket, steam, skirl, rivet etc.), no single suffix dominates - yes.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic adherence: the poem clearly addresses a similar topic to Jabberwocky—a mechanical creature "Screwdrake" and associated conflict with similar structure. Topic clearly adhered to - yes.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext: implied mechanical motif of time and cogs, passage, technology vs. child/hero; undertones of mechanical struggle and care—coherent implied subtext present - yes.</C24_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Murmuration over Stubble

Dusk fell; murmurs skimmed the stubble,  
As whirple-clouds went drift and dip;  
Soft lay field in amber bubble,  
Beneath the swurling swallow-ship.  

Beware the skrindle-gnashwing, child!  
Its flumber-fangs are slick and keen;  
It snoops among the stooks so wild,  
And snaps the dusk to bracken green!  

He gripped his snicker-snodar blade,  
Swish-swoop it sang through briar air;  
With whirple will he stalked the shade,  
And hummed a bold, foreknuckled prayer.  

Thrum-whoop! Skrindle split the stubble,  
Its ember eyes like twin-forged coal;  
Clack! Its flumber-fangs struck double,  
While swurling birds surged round the shoal.  

Then snodar blade went thring-thrang through,  
A spin of sparks, a thunder-yelp;  
He cleft the gnashwing clean in two,  
And stilled its clatter-clinkish help.  

Dusk fell; murmurs skimmed the stubble,  
Now peace-flocked wings went drift and dip;  
Youth strode home, all freed of trouble,  
Beneath the swurling swallow-ship.
label: high
judge_raw:

<C1_think>Title "Murmuration over Stubble" is present as a non-empty line before the first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 6 stanzas total, all quatrains (4 lines each). 6 is between 5 and 8 inclusive. Meets criterion.</C2_think>

<C4_think>Rhyme scheme (2,4) is consistent in most stanzas: for example, st 1 - stubble/ship is not perfect rhyme, but many stanzas have rhymes on lines 2 and 4 ("keen"/"green", "air"/"prayer", "coal"/"shoal", "two"/"help" imperfect but somewhat slant). AABB avoided (no block rhymes). About 4 of 6 stanzas meet rhyme criterion ≥60%. Some rhyme slant but adequate.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza repeats the first stanza nearly verbatim with at least 3 repeated content words/phrases ("Dusk fell", "murmurs skimmed", "stubble", "whirple-clouds" vs "peace-flocked wings" slight variation but overall echo). Ring composition is clear.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Second stanza includes admonition: "Beware the skrindle-gnashwing, child!..." - clear admonition present.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Third stanza shows preparation: protagonist "gripped his ... blade", "stalked the shade", humming a prayer - clear preparation before the encounter.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter is in stanza four: "Thrum-whoop! Skrindle split the stubble..." The adversary appears and confronts protagonist.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Fifth stanza has decisive action: "snodar blade went thring-thrang through", "He cleft the gnashwing clean in two" - decisive slaying present.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Final stanza shows return and celebration: "Youth strode home, all freed of trouble" - joyful resolution and homecoming present.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Invented coinages include: murmuration, whirple-clouds, amber bubble, swurling, skrindle-gnashwing, flumber-fangs, snicker-snodar, thring-thrang, thunder-yelp, clatter-clinkish, bracken green (partial compound). At least 8 distinct invented coinages present.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coinage (e.g. "whirple-clouds", "skrindle-gnashwing", "snicker-snodar", "thring-thrang" etc.), so coinage is well spread.</C12_think>

<C15_think>Multiple stanzas show alliteration/consonance beyond incidental: e.g. "murmurs skimmed the stubble", "flumber-fangs are slick and keen", "snicker-snodar blade", "spin of sparks", "thunder-yelp". At least two stanzas demonstrate this clearly.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order is canonical: warning (2), preparation (3), encounter (4), decisive act (5), return/celebration (6). Order respected clearly.</C16_think>

<C23_think>Topic adherence is strong: poem clearly depicts a stylized invented creature hunt with familiar arc very like Jabberwocky, fitting the topic of a poem in the Jabberwocky style.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext is present: an implied metaphor for facing and overcoming fears or dangers in a fantastical setting, typical of Jabberwocky-like poems, providing an undertone beyond surface action.</C24_think>
